skills.name: Recognise the place value of each digit in integers
Order integers with the same number of digits
Order integers with a different number of digits
Use inequality notation to order integers with the same number of digits
Use inequality notation to order integers with a different number of digits

explanations.A: The 5 is not in the tens column. Use a place value grid, putting the 7 in the units column, the 3 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 5.
explanations.B: The 5 is not in the units column. Use a place value grid, putting the 7 in the units column, the 3 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 5.
explanations.C: If we put this number in a place value grid the number 5 would go in the thousands column. Therefore this 5 represents 5 lots of one thousand which is 5000.
explanations.D: The 5 is not in the ten thousands column. Use a place value grid, putting the 7 in the units column, the 3 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 5.

explanations.A: The 3 is not in the units column. Use a place value grid, putting the 0 in the units column, the 5 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 3.
explanations.B: If we put this number in a place value grid the number 3 would go in the hundred thousands column. Therefore this 3 represents 3 lots of one hundred thousand which is 300,000.
explanations.C: The 3 is not in the ten thousands column. Use a place value grid, putting the 0 in the units column, the 5 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 3.
explanations.D: The 3 is not in the hundreds column. Use a place value grid, putting the 0 in the units column, the 5 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 3.

explanations.A: This list orders the numbers largest to smallest the question asks for smallest to largest.
explanations.B: When comparing numbers always start from the digit with the highest place value, not the smallest. Writing your numbers in a vertical list will help.
explanations.C: Have a look closely at the digits in the hundreds column. 7 hundreds is more than 5 hundreds.
explanations.D: To order these numbers write them underneath each other in a vertical column. Starting from the largest digit, compare the numbers within the same place value column. If two or more of the numbers have the same digit in any one column move to the next column to compare. Doing this we can see that option D orders these numbers from smallest to largest.

explanations.A: To order these numbers write them underneath each other in a vertical column. Starting from the largest digit, compare the numbers within the same place value column. If two or more of the numbers have the same digit in any one column move to the next column to compare. Doing this we can see that option A orders these numbers from smallest to largest.
explanations.B: This list orders the numbers largest to smallest the question asks for smallest to largest.
explanations.C: Have a look closely at the digits in the tens column. 7 tens is more than 0 tens.
explanations.D: When comparing numbers always start from the digit with the highest place value, not the smallest. Writing your numbers in a vertical list will help.

explanations.A: This list orders the numbers largest to smallest the question asks for smallest to largest.
explanations.B: Make sure you are comparing digits with the same place value. Writing your numbers in a vertical column, lining up the numbers with the same place value will help.
explanations.C: To order these numbers write them underneath each other in a vertical column, lining up the digits with the same place value. Starting from the largest place value, compare the numbers within that column. If two or more of the numbers have the same digit in any one column move to the next column to compare. Doing this we can see that option C orders these numbers from smallest to largest.
explanations.D: When comparing numbers always start from the digit with the highest place value, not the smallest. Writing your numbers in a vertical list, lining up the digits with the same place value will help.

explanations.A: Make sure you are comparing digits with the same place value. Writing your numbers in a vertical column, lining up the numbers with the same place value will help.
explanations.B: To order these numbers write them underneath each other in a vertical column, lining up the digits with the same place value. Starting from the largest digit, compare the numbers within the same place value column. If two or more of the numbers have the same digit in any one column move to the next column to compare. Doing this we can see that option C orders these numbers from smallest to largest.
explanations.C: When comparing numbers always start from the digit with the highest place value, not the smallest. Writing your numbers in a vertical list, lining up the digits with the same place value will help.
explanations.D: So close! This list orders the numbers largest to smallest the question asks for smallest to largest.

explanations.A: When comparing these numbers always start with the number in the highest place value column, not the smallest. Remember the inequality sign always points towards the smallest number.
explanations.B: Comparing the ten thousands column we can see that these numbers are not equal. Is the number on the left less or more than the number on the right? Which inequality sign would we use to show this?
explanations.C: We can put one of these symbols in the empty box. Remember the inequality sign points towards the smallest number.
explanations.D: Both numbers have the same number of millions and hundred thousands. 1,959,909 has 5 ten thousands but 1,995,902 has 9 ten thousands. Therefore 1,959,909 is less than 1,995,902.

explanations.A: Both numbers have the same number of millions and hundred thousands. 6,732,591 has 3 ten thousands but 6,723,519 has 2 ten thousands. Therefore 6,732,591 is more than 6,723,519.
explanations.B: When comparing these numbers always start with the number in the highest place value column, not the smallest. Remember the inequality sign always points towards the smallest number.
explanations.C: Comparing the ten thousands column we can see that these numbers are not equal. Is the number on the left less or more than the number on the right? Which inequality sign would we use to show this?
explanations.D: We can put one of these symbols in the empty box. Remember the inequality sign points towards the smallest number.

explanations.A: Remember to compare the digits with the same place value. Writing these numbers underneath each other, lining up the place value will help.
explanations.B: Writing these numbers underneath each other, ensuring that we line up the digits with the same place value, shows that 1 million is greater than 0 millions, 995,999 has no millions,. Therefore 1,000,000 is greater than 995,999.
explanations.C: Comparing the digits in the one million column we can see that these numbers are not equal. Is the number on the left less or more than the number on the right? Which inequality sign would we use to show this?
explanations.D: We can put one of these symbols in the empty box. Remember the inequality sign points towards the smallest number.

explanations.A: Writing these numbers underneath each other, ensuring that we line up the digits with the same place value, shows that 2 million is greater than 0 millions, 725,912 has no millions,. Therefore 725,912 is less than 2,705,291.
explanations.B: Remember to compare the digits with the same place value. Writing these numbers underneath each other, lining up the place value will help.
explanations.C: We can put one of these symbols in the empty box. Remember the inequality sign points towards the smallest number.
explanations.D: Comparing the digits in the one million column we can see that these numbers are not equal. Is the number on the left less or more than the number on the right? Which inequality sign would we use to show this?
